div.l: And gan awake and wente hir out to pis
And cam ayen ⁊and gan her cradil mys
And gropid here ⁊and þere but she fond non
Allas ꝙquod she I hadde almost mysgon̄
I hadde almost goon̄ to þe clerkis bed
Do wey benedicite thanne hadde I foule sped
And forth she goth til she þe cradil fond
She gropith alwey ferther with her hond
And fond the bed and þouȝte nouȝt but good
Be cause the Cradil be it stood
And nyste never where she was for it was derk
But fair͗e and wel she crepte vnto þe clerk
And lith ful stille ⁊and wolde haue cauȝt a sleep̄e
With ynne a while this Iohn vp leep̄e
And on this good wif he leyeth on sore
So mery A fit hadde not she not ful yore
He prikith harde and depe as he were mad
This ioli liff haue thise two clerkis lad
Til þat the thridde cok began to synge
Aleyn wext wery in the dawnynge
For he hadde swonken al the longe nyȝt
And saide fare wel my lady swete wiȝt
The day is come I may no lenger bide
Ȝit evermore where so y go or ride
I am thin owen clerk sa haue I hele
Now dere lemman ꝙquod she go fare wele
But or thow go o thing I wol þe telle
When þat thow wendist homward by þᵉ melle
Riȝt atte entre of þe dore behynde
Thow shalt a cake of half a busshel fynde
That was I maad of thyn owen corn̄ corn̄ mele
Which þat I halp my self forto stele
And gode lemman god the saue ⁊and kepe
And with þat word almost she gan to wepe
Aleyn vprist ⁊and þouȝte or þᵗat it dawe
I wil go crepe yn be my felawe
